content.text: RFC 9003 (published Feb 2021) adds human-readable shutdown messages to BGP.
Before this, operators had to guess why a BGP session was shut down.
1. All BGP messages start with a 19-byte header:
‚Ä¢ Marker: 16 bytes of 0xFF (synchronization)
‚Ä¢ Length: 2 bytes (total message size, big-endian)
‚Ä¢ Type: 1 byte (1=OPEN, 2=UPDATE, 3=NOTIFICATION, 4=KEEPALIVE)
Used to report errors and close BGP connections. Structure:
‚Ä¢ Error Code: 1 byte (6 = Cease)
‚Ä¢ Subcode: 1 byte (2 = Admin Shutdown, 4 = Admin Reset)
‚Ä¢ Data: Variable length (RFC 9003 adds UTF-8 message here!)
The shutdown message is encoded as:
‚Ä¢ Length: 1 byte (0-255, size of UTF-8 message)
‚Ä¢ Message: UTF-8 encoded text (max 255 bytes)
[Marker:16][Length:2][Type:1][Error:1][Subcode:1][MsgLen:1][UTF8-Message:0-255]
Total size: 22 bytes minimum (empty message) to 277 bytes maximum
‚Ä¢ "Upgrading to 1.2.3, back in 30min" - Planned maintenance
‚Ä¢ "[TICKET-123] Emergency fiber cut repair" - Unplanned outage
‚Ä¢ "Moving to new peer AS64512" - Configuration change
‚Ä¢ UTF-8 support means emojis work! "Maintenance üîß"
‚Ä¢ Cyrillic, Chinese, Arabic all supported
‚Ä¢ 255 bytes ‚âà 255 ASCII chars, but only ~85 Chinese chars
‚Ä¢ Helps network operators worldwide communicate better
BGP NOTIFICATION messages are nuclear options - they ALWAYS kill the session.
This isn't a bug, it's a feature. Here's why:
1. BGP is paranoid by design. Config mismatch? Dead session. Bad message? Dead.
Hold timer expired? Dead. Any error? Dead. No exceptions.
2. "Just send a warning" is how you get routing loops and blackholes.
The Internet works because BGP fails closed, not open.
3. RFC 9003 only covers Admin Shutdown/Reset because those are the ONLY cases
where you're intentionally killing a working session. Every other
NOTIFICATION is BGP saying "something is broken, I'm out."
1: Message Header Error - Malformed message, probable attack
2: OPEN Message Error - Config mismatch, AS numbers wrong
3: UPDATE Message Error - Bad routes, potential hijack
4: Hold Timer Expired - Peer is dead or network is
5: FSM Error - State machine broken, memory corruption?
6: Cease - Voluntary termination (only 2 & 4 get messages)
Want to tell your peer their config is wrong without dropping?
Use email. Or phone. Or literally anything except BGP.
BGP's job is moving packets, not messages. It speaks in routes and
silence. When it does speak (NOTIFICATION), someone's day is ruined.
This is good design. Complexity is where bugs hide, and bugs in BGP
mean the Internet breaks. Keep it simple, keep it brutal.
Message: "Test" (4 bytes) with subcode 2:
ff ff ff ff ff ff ff ff ff ff ff ff ff ff ff ff  [Marker]
00 1a                                              [Length: 26]
03                                                 [Type: NOTIFICATION]
06                                                 [Error: Cease]
02                                                 [Subcode: Admin Shutdown]
04                                                 [Message Length: 4]
